    This is true for any a,b∈Ra, b \in \Ra,b∈R. In particular, swapping aaa and bbb gives the inequality

    ∣b∣−∣a∣≤∣b−a∣=∣a−b∣.  ⟹  −∣a−b∣≤∣a∣−∣b∣.\abs{b} - \abs{a} \leq \abs{b - a} = \abs{a - b}. \implies -\abs{a - b} \leq \abs{a} - \abs{b}.∣b∣−∣a∣≤∣b−a∣=∣a−b∣.⟹−∣a−b∣≤∣a∣−∣b∣.

A lot of you did something like this for part (1) in the "  ⟹  \implies⟹" direction: You showed

Solution 2 (direct proof)

While this proof technically requires a proof by induction, I won't be picky about it as long as the main details are present in your proof. I'll prove the following statement by induction:

Pn=‘‘there exist r1,…,rn∈Q such that a<r1<⋯<rn<b".P_n = ``\text{there exist } r_1, \ldots, r_n \in \Q \text{ such that } a < r_1 < \cdots < r_n < b".Pn​=‘‘there exist r1​,…,rn​∈Q such that a<r1​<⋯<rn​<b".

Note that in PnP_nPn​, r1,…,rnr_1, \ldots, r_nr1​,…,rn​ are all distinct because of the strict inequalities.

Base case: When n=1n = 1n=1, we use density of Q\QQ on (a,b)\p{a, b}(a,b) to find r1∈Qr_1 \in \Qr1​∈Q such that a<r1<ba < r_1 < ba<r1​<b.

Inductive step: Suppose we have r1,…,rn∈Qr_1, \ldots, r_n \in \Qr1​,…,rn​∈Q such that a<r1<⋯<rn<ba < r_1 < \cdots < r_n < ba<r1​<⋯<rn​<b. By density of Q\QQ applied to the interval (rn,b)\p{r_n, b}(rn​,b), we obtain rn+1∈Qr_{n+1} \in \Qrn+1​∈Q such that rn<rn+1<br_n < r_{n+1} < brn​<rn+1​<b.

Thus, for every n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, there exists at least nnn rational numbers in (a,b)\p{a, b}(a,b), so there must exist infinitely many rational numbers in (a,b)\p{a, b}(a,b).

Common Mistakes

The main issue I saw with proofs was that students just said to "repeat this process" infinitely many times, but "this process" was not very clearly defined. For example, I saw this multiple times:

By density of Q\QQ, there exists r1∈Qr_1 \in \Qr1​∈Q such that a<r1<ba < r_1 < ba<r1​<b. By density again, there exists r2∈Qr_2 \in \Qr2​∈Q such that r1<r2<br_1 < r_2 < br1​<r2​<b. Repeating this process, we get infinitely many rational numbers between aaa and bbb.

While the idea is correct, the details are not all there. For example, how should I pick the endpoints for the next step? If I used r1<br_1 < br1​<b again, then I would get r3∈Qr_3 \in \Qr3​∈Q such that r1<r3<br_1 < r_3 < br1​<r3​<b. However, maybe I'm unlucky and it turns out that r3=r2r_3 = r_2r3​=r2​. You have to describe a process that lets me always pick a brand new rational number.
